author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Who Should Get Reparations in California?
description: A task force in charge of the state’s reparations effort, the first in the nation, is struggling to decide which Black Californians should receive payments.
content: If California were to provide reparations for Black residents, who exactly should qualify for the payments?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: A doctor prominent in fomenting opposition to Covid vaccines pleads guilty to Capitol riot charges.
description: The founder of America’s Frontline Doctors, a group that spreads pandemic misinformation, stood by as a Capitol Police officer was assaulted, then entered the Capitol and made a speech against Covid vaccines, according to a Justice Department filing.
content: The founder of America’s Frontline Doctors, an activist group known for spreading misinformation and conspiracy theories about the pandemic and Covid vaccines, has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge related to the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Emotionally Intelligent Are You?
description: Are you good at recognizing emotions in yourself and others?
content: Do you consider yourself “emotionally intelligent”? In other words, are you able to identify and acknowledge feelings in yourself or others? How important do you think it is to be able to do that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Russia’s Brutal Advance
description: It’s creating a humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.
content: The war in Ukraine is a mismatch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: loquacious
description: This word has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn S. Gerstell
title: I’ve Dealt With Foreign Cyberattacks. America Isn’t Ready for What’s Coming.
description: U.S. leaders must rethink the current cyberdefense system and rally around a centralized regulator.
content: As Russian missiles rain on Ukraine, there’s another battle brewing — in the cybersphere. Destructive malware has flooded hundreds of Ukrainian websites and computers since Vladimir Putin announced his invasion. It would be a mistake to assume such attacks will remain limited to Ukrainian targets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Marx
title: Their Interfaith Relationship Turned a Corner on Christmas
description: For Caressa Gonzalez, who is Catholic, and Mordechai Miltz, who was raised Orthodox Jewish, things got serious when he crashed her family’s holiday celebration.
content: [Click here to binge read this week’s featured couples.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Yes, Your Pets Can Also Put On Pandemic Pounds
description: Dogs and cats have surprised their owners by gaining weight during the coronavirus pandemic. Veterinarians blame the extra treats and table scraps.
content: It had been a year since Henry’s last haircut, and Michelle Holbrook did not realize that her 7-pound, goofy toy poodle was now almost 9 pounds. His cute, shaggy look not only obscured his weight, it also made it harder for the Holbrooks to resist his begging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Marsh
title: Boiling Oil, Red-Hot Irons, 26-Second Amputations: How Surgery Evolved
description: Ira Rutkow’s “Empire of the Scalpel” is by turns fascinating and ghastly.
content: EMPIRE OF THE SCALPEL: The History of Surgery, by Ira Rutkow
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Joni James, 91, Heartfelt Chanteuse of the 1950s, Dies
description: A top-selling artist known as the “Queen of Hearts,” she had a voice tinged with longing and melancholy and was an early influence on Barbra Streisand.
content: Joni James, a best-selling chanteuse whose records climbed the Billboard charts in the 1950s and who was an early influence on Barbra Streisand, died on Feb. 20 in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Shaman
title: What Will Our Covid Future Be Like? Here Are Two Signs to Look Out For.
description: How to come to terms with the uncertainty.
content: Omicron cases, hospitalizations and deaths have been substantially declining across the United States for more than a month. In response, governors and mayors are rolling back restrictions like mask mandates and vaccine passports. Many wonder whether this period of low cases and decreasing demands on hospitals is a turning point in the pandemic or is simply a lull before a new variant causes another dangerous surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: How a War Helped Ease a Rift Between Britain and the E.U.
description: The crisis in Ukraine is beginning to narrow the chasm opened up by Brexit.
content: LONDON — It took the invasion of a sovereign nation, the bombardment of its cities and the continent’s biggest security challenge in decades to make it happen. But for the first time in years, Britain and the European Union are working together again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Roberts
title: Female Entrepreneurs Who Confront a Particular Kind of Troll
description: Food companies founded by Asian American women find social media engagement with customers helps their growth, but they also face racist and sexist comments.
content: Fly By Jing, an artisanal food business in Los Angeles, is known for its Sichuan chili crisp and good-humored online presence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juli Fraga and Connie Chang
title: Jealousy Doesn’t Have to Ruin a Friendship
description: Everyone feels left out sometimes. It’s how you handle it that matters.
content: When Bob Bergeson’s friend invited him to a Denver Nuggets basketball game with some new pals, he was excited to join in. Sure, the evening would cost him nearly $400, an amount he wouldn’t normally spend. But Mr. Bergeson’s splurge didn’t reflect a slavish devotion to basketball; he opened his wallet because he felt insecure about his languishing relationship with his friend, who he perceived to be getting closer to a new group of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Panel Suggests Trump Knew He Lost the Election, Eyeing Criminal Case
description: At the core of the theory of a possible criminal case against former President Donald J. Trump is the argument that he knew he had lost the election and sought to overturn it anyway.
content: WASHINGTON — Shortly after the 2020 election, as ballots were still being counted, the top data expert in President Donald J. Trump’s re-election campaign told him bluntly that he was going to lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Pistols, Assault Rifles, Zip Ties: Witness Describes Preparation for Jan. 6
description: A witness in the trial of Guy Reffitt, the first person to face a jury on charges stemming from the Capitol assault, said they wanted to be prepared in case “something bad happened.”
content: WASHINGTON — Just before they went to hear President Donald J. Trump speak on the day of the Capitol riot last year, Rocky Hardie, at the time a member of a Texas militia, and a friend, Guy Wesley Reffitt, made their preparations, Mr. Hardie testified in federal court on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: How Bad Is Inflation, Really?
description: Economists and Americans alike are trying to make sense of prices, wages and public opinion.
content: This morning, the Labor Department will report how many jobs employers added to their payrolls in February. Economists expect a healthy gain. (For full coverage of the report, see The Times’s special briefing, which will be updated throughout the day.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: U.S. Grants Temporary Protected Status to Some Ukrainians
description: The designation gives Ukrainians who were in the United States without legal documentation as of March 1 permission to stay and work for 18 months.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Thursday it would offer humanitarian relief to Ukrainians who have been living in the country without legal documentation since March 1 or earlier, signaling additional support for citizens of Ukraine as Russia advanced in the south of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Judge Blocks Effort to Disqualify Cawthorn from Ballot as ‘Insurrectionist’
description: A district judge ruled that the Amnesty Act of 1872, which forgave confederates, overruled a clause in the 14th Amendment barring “insurrectionists” from Congress.
content: WASHINGTON — A judge on Friday blocked a novel electoral challenge that sought to disqualify Representative Madison Cawthorn of North Carolina from running for re-election by labeling him an insurrectionist, issuing an equally novel order that invoked a post-Civil War law that forgave confederate soldiers and sympathizers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: A.T.F., Agency Crucial to Biden’s Gun Plan, Struggles to Push for Reform
description: Critics accuse the A.T.F.’s acting director, Marvin Richardson, of cozying up to gun industry leaders at a convention in Las Vegas and delaying enacting rules that would outlaw so-called ghost guns.
content: WASHINGTON — In late January, days before President Biden reiterated a vow to halt the sale of parts used to make deadly “ghost guns,” the federal official responsible for enacting that policy delivered a far more reassuring message to the gun industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Russia’s War Prompts a Pitch for ‘Socially Responsible’ Military Stocks
description: Bombs, guns and fighter jets aren’t typical E.S.G. investments, but two Citi analysts say they should be. Advocates for “socially responsible” investing call the idea “absurd.”
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has upset the world order. It could conceivably alter the way some people think about investing, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Andrew S. Curran
title: We Need a New Language for Talking About Race
description: In the 18th century, “scientific” myths about race sought to divide people into separate groups. Today, new DNA science is revealing just how connected we really are.
content: The other day, while teaching a lecture class, one of us mentioned in passing that the average African American, according to a 2014 paper, is about 24 percent European and less than 1 percent Native American. A student responded that these percentages were impossible to measure, since “race is a social construction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vicki Constantine Croke
title: A Natural (and Political and Cultural) History of America’s Bird
description: In “The Bald Eagle,” Jack E. Davis takes a wide-angle view on the decline and recent resurgence of his title subject.
content: THE BALD EAGLEThe Improbable Journey of America’s BirdBy Jack E. Davis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Luxury giants LVMH and Hermès will close stores in Russia temporarily.
description: The French brands join other Western companies in pausing retail operations as the Russian invasion of Ukraine escalates.
content: The French luxury giants LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton and Hermès each said Friday that they would temporarily close their stores in Russia as the crisis in Ukraine continued to escalate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: China Turns Away from the World Under Xi and How to Talk to Kids About Ukraine: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: The War in Ukraine Holds a Warning for the World Order
description: The multinational response shows that liberalism has some life left. But the challenges posed by waning U.S. power and rising authoritarianism remain formidable.
content: The liberal world order has been on life support for a while. President Biden, in his inaugural address, called democracy “fragile.” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said two years ago that “the liberal idea” had “outlived its purpose,” while China’s leader, Xi Jinping, has extolled the strength of an all-powerful state and, as he put it last March, “self-confidence in our system.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Greene and Boebert, Democrats See a Helpful Political Target
description: The antics of Representatives Marjorie Taylor Greene and Lauren Boebert, as well as recent stumbles by other Republicans, have drawn unflattering attention to their party.
content: WASHINGTON — Representatives Marjorie Taylor Greene and Lauren Boebert are two backbench freshmen in the House minority, powerless in the official hierarchy and unlikely to gain much power even in a likely Republican majority next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: How Stacey Abrams Thinks About Business
description: In a new book, the candidate for Georgia governor delves into lessons she learned as a business owner. She says they’ve been useful for politics, too.
content: Stacey Abrams is best known as a champion for voting rights and a rising star in the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘It’s Not About Me’: Scherzer Bucks a System That Worked for Him
description: A Mets ace, Max Scherzer stands to lose around $233,000 per day because of canceled games. He wants to fix the system for players who make exponentially less.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — Max Scherzer drives a Porsche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: The Starrett-Lehigh Building, at 90, Prepares for Its Future
description: The venerable city landmark, a star of industrial modernism when it opened, is adding amenities for commercial tenants, especially in creative fields.
content: When the gargantuan Starrett-Lehigh Building went up in West Chelsea in 1931, it was quickly hailed as a masterwork of industrial modernism, a triumph both of engineering and of International Style architectural aesthetics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: After Many Steps, a First Date
description: Daniela Grafman and Jonathan Juarbe connected on an app in the early pandemic, then walked — she from the Upper East Side, and he across the Brooklyn Bridge — to meet in person.
content: [Click here to binge read this week’s featured couples.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Catch up on the latest news on Ukraine.
description: Russian troops in southeastern Ukraine have seized Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, Ukrainian officials said on Friday, but a fire there that had raised worldwide alarms was extinguished. There had been worries that the fire could spread to nuclear reactors and lead to radiation leaks, but international monitors said Friday morning that there was no immediate sign that radiation had leaked during the battle for the plant.
content: Russian troops in southeastern Ukraine have seized Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, Ukrainian officials said on Friday, but a fire there that had raised worldwide alarms was extinguished. There had been worries that the fire could spread to nuclear reactors and lead to radiation leaks, but international monitors said Friday morning that there was no immediate sign that radiation had leaked during the battle for the plant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: In a Moment of Crisis, These Women Went to Work
description: The pandemic took a terrible toll on women in the workplace; these three redefined their working lives.
content: By now, negative headlines about female employment over the past two years tell a familiar story. Many women, who already bore responsibility for the majority of unpaid domestic labor, were forced by the pandemic to retreat from their roles in the professional world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Ukraine War Forces a Question: How Far East Does Europe Go?
description: After Russia invaded, Ukraine asked to join the European Union, quickly. Moldova and Georgia have asked, too. Member states would rather not answer.
content: BRUSSELS — Ukrainians waved European Union flags when they put their lives on the line in 2014 during their revolution in Maidan Square, in the center of Kyiv, provoked by their desire to draw closer to the West. It was a pivotal moment, choosing Europe over Russia and incurring the Kremlin’s wrath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: What Putin’s war could mean for fossil fuels
description: Also in this edition of the newsletter: A map that shows imperiled biodiversity in the lower 48 states.
content: How do you ensure energy security on a hotter planet? That’s the thorny new question that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine presents to many countries, most immediately in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: At the Philharmonic, a Conductor Is the Star
description: In a program without soloist vehicles, the focus was on Herbert Blomstedt, a 94-year-old elder statesman of classical music.
content: It’s probably safe to say that Herbert Blomstedt will not be the New York Philharmonic’s next music director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Goldberg Sloan
title: Erin Entrada Kelly on the Stranger Within
description: When a mysterious outsider joins a small-town Louisiana classroom, in Erin Entrada Kelly’s “Those Kids From Fawn Creek,” everything changes.
content: THOSE KIDS FROM FAWN CREEKBy Erin Entrada Kelly
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein, Amy Chang Chien and Chang W. Lee
title: Paralympics President Rebukes Russia at Opening Ceremony
description: Andrew Parsons denounced Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, a notable act given the International Olympic Committee’s ban on protests and political messages.
content: BEIJING — The president of the International Paralympic Committee broke protocol on Friday when he denounced Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in his speech at the opening ceremony of the Beijing Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Meet Peat, the Unsung Hero of Carbon Capture’
description: In this lesson, students will read an illustrated article to learn how mossy wetlands could help slow climate change.
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Jewish New Yorkers Unite to Raise Millions for Ukraine
description: New York City is home to some 300,000 Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union.
content: Rabbi Labish Becker, the executive director of Agudath Israel of America, an umbrella organization of ultra-Orthodox Jewish groups, has raised more than $2 million for Ukraine since the Russian invasion. He said the emergence of President Volodymyr Zelensky, who is Jewish, as “a Ukrainian national hero,” has been “a source of pride for people” amid the grim news of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Changes to Settlement Could Aid Thousands of Black Players’ Claims
description: A judge approved a race-neutral plan which will force the administrator of the N.F.L. concussions settlement to rescore dementia tests taken by several thousand Black former players who had submitted claims.
content: The federal judge overseeing the N.F.L. concussion settlement formally removed the use of a race-based method to evaluate dementia tests of Black former players, paving the way for thousands of players to file claims worth potentially hundreds of thousands of dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Alan Ladd Jr., Hitmaking Film Executive, Dies at 84
description: When other studios didn’t want it, he took on the project that became “Star Wars.” He later guided “Chariots of Fire,” “Young Frankenstein” and numerous other movies.
content: Alan Ladd Jr., who as a producer and studio executive was a guiding hand behind scores of successful films, none bigger than “Star Wars,” which he championed when its young director, George Lucas, was having trouble getting it made, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: A suit filed by the A.C.L.U. accuses ICE jailers of denying detainees vaccines.
description: One of the plaintiffs is Anna Sorokin, a Russian immigrant who for several years presented herself as a German heiress named Anna Delvey. She received a booster shot on Thursday, two days after the suit was filed.
content: People with health conditions that place them at high risk from Covid-19 have been denied access to coronavirus vaccine booster shots while in federal immigration detention, the American Civil Liberties Union said in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us About the Books That Shaped You
description: We want to hear about the books that have most affected our readers’ lives.
content: What are the books that made you see the world a little differently? The books that inspired you or taught you something new? The books that made you … you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: How Scarves Became a Staple in Soccer Culture
description: In Thursday’s puzzle, SCARF was the answer to the clue “Accessory for a soccer fan.”
content: This is Clued In, a column that will give you insight into some of the New York Times Crossword clues and answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Shane Warne, One of Cricket’s Masters of Spin, Dies at 52
description: Warne’s management company said the Australian star died Friday of a suspected heart attack.
content: Shane Warne, one of the greatest cricket players of all time, and a larger-than-life figure on and off the field, died Friday in Thailand. He was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Klara and the Sun’ and ‘The Committed’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: KLARA AND THE SUN, by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Vintage, 320 pp., $16.95.) Ishiguro’s eighth novel, about a humanoid machine that serves as a companion for a sickly teenager, is about love and humanity in a world where workers have been largely replaced by machines. With “Klara and the Sun,” our reviewer, Radhika Jones, commented, Ishiguro “has mastered the adjacent theme of obsolescence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Consumer Agency Weighs Ban on Medical Debts in Credit Reports
description: More than half of the debt that appears on credit reports as being in collection stems from medical bills, the agency found.
content: Unpaid medical bills became a bigger concern during the pandemic, and now, a federal consumer agency is considering whether those debts should be banned from consumer credit reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Need Help in a Hospital? Call a Patient Advocate
description: Most hospitals have designated problem solvers on staff, but many people don’t know how to find them.
content: Hospitals are tough to navigate during normal times, and they’ve become even more complicated during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana Nguyen, Rachel Quester, Lisa Tobin, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Death of the Competitive Congressional District
description: The first primaries of the 2022 midterm elections show the power of the redistricting process.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Slowing Economy Tops Agenda at Legislative Session
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine went unmentioned at the opening of an annual gathering of China’s legislature, as leaders focused on stabilizing economic growth.
content: BEIJING — When China’s legislature opened its weeklong annual session on Saturday, Chinese leaders were eager to use the event to bolster confidence in the country’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: America’s Very Peculiar Economic Funk
description: Negative views of the economy don’t match people’s experience.
content: I’ve been on a few trips recently and took the opportunity to do a bit of naked-eye economic assessment. As I’m sure many people can confirm, planes are flying full, while shops and restaurants are jammed. It definitely looks like a booming economy out there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: How China Embraces Russian Propaganda and Its Version of the War
description: In much of the world, Russia is losing the information war over Ukraine. In China, though, it’s winning big.
content: Hours after Russia invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, the Chinese Communist Party tabloid, Global Times, posted a video saying that a large number of Ukrainian soldiers had laid down their arms. Its source: the Russian state-controlled television network, RT.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: The F.D.A. rejects an India-made Covid vaccine for those under 18.
description: The vaccine, made by Bharat Biotech, is widely used in India. It has not been tested in the U.S., which has not authorized it for any age groups.
content: The American pharmaceutical company Ocugen said on Friday that the Food and Drug Administration had rejected its application seeking emergency authorization for an India-made Covid vaccine for those ages 2 to 18.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Sony and Honda Announce Tie-Up to Make Electric Cars
description: The two Japanese giants said they would form a company that would make battery-powered cars in Honda’s factories.
content: TOKYO — The Japanese electronics and entertainment giant Sony announced on Friday that it would team up with Honda to develop electric cars for sale as early as 2025, becoming the latest company to throw its hat into the burgeoning market for battery-powered vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Brilliant Alchemy of Rick Owens
description: How one designer turned the tenor of the moment into beauty. Plus protective covering at Balmain and immersive surrealism at Dries Van Noten.
content: PARIS — A few months ago, when the designer Rick Owens started thinking about his fall collection, he was thinking about Covid and the re-emergence, and discos, and parties, and whether all of that was good or bad, and how he had mixed feelings, and so on and so forth. Sound familiar? But then last week happened, and everything changed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remote work is changing how climbing the career ladder works.
description: Remote work is often favored by established employees who know their manager, are comfortable in their role and want to balance work with family responsibilities or other personal obligations. For those just starting their careers, working in isolation can make fitting into an organization — and eventually progressing up its ranks — more difficult.
content: Remote work is often favored by established employees who know their manager, are comfortable in their role and want to balance work with family responsibilities or other personal obligations. For those just starting their careers, working in isolation can make fitting into an organization — and eventually progressing up its ranks — more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger
title: NATO Accuses Russia of Using Cluster Bombs in Ukraine
description: Officials made the accusation Friday as part of a display of a unified front in support of Ukraine, but rejected a plea from Kyiv to impose a no-fly zone over its airspace.
content: BRUSSELS — NATO officials, determined to show a unified front of support for Ukraine, on Friday accused Russia of using cluster bombs in its invasion, but rejected Kyiv’s plea to impose a no-fly zone over Ukrainian airspace, fearing that would draw the military alliance into a larger war with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Winning Time’: When the N.B.A. Went Pop
description: A new HBO drama chronicles the 1980s Lakers, whose fluid style and Hollywood flair changed the game and the culture. An N.B.A. writer takes account.
content: When asked to describe the 1980s Los Angeles Lakers, the actor DeVaughn Nixon, 38, paused for a moment. “Stylized,” he said. Then he rattled off more words: “Fast. Cool. Fun. Sexy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill and Dmitriy Khavin
title: Videos show scenes from one occupied Ukrainian city.
description: ​​Videos verified by The New York Times show some residents of Melitopol meeting Russian troops with a mix of anger and scorn, and others lining up for aid in a central square.
content: ​​Videos posted on Thursday and verified by The New York Times reveal the various ways residents of Melitopol, a city under Russian occupation for at least three days, are coping with the presence of foreign troops in their city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Dan Graham, Mind-Bending Conceptual Artist, Dies at 79
description: Best known for his large mirrored installations, he played with ideas about spectacle and perception in a vast array of genres.
content: Dan Graham, a contrarian polymath best known, despite his protests, as a conceptual artist, died on Feb. 19 in Manhattan. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Charlie Savage
title: Pressure on Justice Dept. as Jan. 6 Panel Lays Out Case Against Trump
description: Building a criminal case against the former president is very difficult for federal prosecutors, experts say, underlining the dilemma confronting the agency.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is facing mounting pressure to prosecute former President Donald J. Trump after the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack laid out its argument for a potential criminal case on Wednesday night, placing Attorney General Merrick B. Garland squarely in the middle of a politically charged debate over how to hold Mr. Trump accountable for efforts to overturn the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: With ‘Lucy and Desi,’ Amy Poehler Gets to the Heart of a Marriage
description: The performer and director wanted to deliver a down-to-earth portrayal of a couple whose union was far from perfect, even if viewers wouldn’t accept that.
content: Near the beginning of the new Amy Poehler-directed documentary, “Lucy and Desi,” an audio recording plays. In it, Lucille Ball thanks her husband, Desi Arnaz, for her two beautiful, healthy children. That’s not exactly a shocking statement coming from a woman in 1950s America. What’s surprising is that Ball finishes by thanking her husband for her “freedom.” It’s one of many moments in the film that might cause those who think they know the story of these stars, and this couple, to lean in a little closer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney+ Will Introduce a Cheaper, Ad-Supported Version This Year
description: The announcement comes as Disney faces pressure to keep its streaming business growing.
content: Disney+ will soon be available at a reduced price, but you’ll have to sit through commercials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Great School Unmasking
description: More states are lifting school mask requirements.
content: As cases across the country plummet, more states are lifting mask mandates — and schools are following suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: Skater Beatrice Domond Makes a Splash
description: The 26-year-old is the first woman to join Supreme’s skate team.
content: Name: Beatrice Domond
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marzano-Lesnevich
title: Who Should Be Allowed to Transition?
description: In many places, governments rely on poorly trained outside experts to decide whether someone is “truly”  trans.
content: Two and a half years ago, I sat in a medical waiting room nervously rehearsing my reason for seeing the nurse practitioner. The words I needed to say to her — that I was transgender and wanted her help medically transitioning — I had once promised myself not to say to anyone. I thought I’d keep this part of my identity my deepest secret, one I’d known since childhood but would never reveal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Why Your Boss Wants to Know Your Love Language
description: Free tacos, shopping sprees and words of appreciation are just some of the ways employers are desperate to show they care.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Economic Ties Among Nations Spur Peace. Or Do They?
description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine strains the long-held idea that shared interests around business and commerce can deflect military conflict.
content: Russia’s war in Ukraine is not only reshaping the strategic and political order in Europe, it is also upending long-held assumptions about the intricate connections that are a signature of the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: With His Sci-Fi Android, a Filmmaker Considers What It Means to Be Alive
description: Kogonada, whose new film is the futuristic A.I. drama “After Yang,” reflects on the nature of his work, and of existence.
content: Kogonada distinctly remembers the first time the specter of nonexistence dawned upon him. He was alone in his room, and it was a weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Ambulance wait times are as long as a day in Hong Kong amid an Omicron surge.
description: Waiting for an ambulance in Hong Kong can take more than a day as the city reels from a surge in Omicron cases and its hospitals, doctors and nurses are stretched thin.
content: Waiting for an ambulance in Hong Kong can take more than a day as the city reels from a surge in Omicron cases and its hospitals, doctors and nurses are stretched thin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Boutique-Fragrance Expert Spends Her Sundays
description: Kimberly Waters runs a perfume parlor, of sorts, out of her Harlem townhouse.
content: Kimberly Waters is the founder of Muse: Modern Urban Sensory Experiences, a niche fragrance business that she runs out of her home on the weekends. A visit to Muse is by appointment only and includes cocktails and snacks. The main event is a guided tour of Ms. Waters’s curated perfume collection, with bottles available for purchase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Tesla Wins Approval to Open European Assembly Plant
description: German authorities cleared the plant, which was built near Berlin, to open for production. Tesla plans to build 500,000 electric cars a year there.
content: BERLIN — German authorities gave the approval on Friday for Tesla to begin production of electric vehicles and battery cells at its first major assembly plant in Europe, after months of delays and disputes, paving the way for the electric car company to begin production of its Model Y sport utility vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Khan and Salman Masood
title: ISIS Claims Bombing of Pakistani Mosque, Killing Dozens
description: More than 50 people were killed and more than 100 wounded after an explosion tore through a Shiite mosque in one of the worst terrorist attacks in Pakistan in years.
content: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A bomb tore through a Shiite mosque in Peshawar, in northwestern Pakistan, on Friday, killing at least 57 people and wounding more than 100 in one of the worst terrorist attacks in Pakistan in several years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Harry Belafonte Turns 95 With a Call for Social Justice
description: Spike Lee, Cornel West, and Alicia Keys turn out to celebrate an entertainer who put his career on the line for the cause.
content: “He put his money where his mouth is, and he put his career on the line,” said Laurence Fishburne at a gala Tuesday night celebrating the 95th birthday of Harry Belafonte, the groundbreaking entertainer whose fight for racial justice may prove an even more lasting legacy. “And he looked pretty while he was doing it.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Cancel Carnival? Group of Artists Has Other Ideas.
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 4, 2022.
content: “The music produces a vibration that reaches your heart and gives you emotion. And you sing, dance, jump, get happy and forget everything. Then you come back to reality.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: The Fight Over ‘Maus’ Is Part of a Bigger Cultural Battle in Tennessee
description: State lawmakers, led by the governor, are rethinking what public school students should read and learn.
content: ATHENS, Tenn. — After the McMinn County School Board voted in January to remove “Maus,” a graphic novel about the Holocaust, from its eighth-grade curriculum, the community quickly found itself at the center of a national frenzy over book censorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Ukraine’s Call to Arms
description: Civilians are being armed en masse — and there is no recent precedent.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Kevin Granville
title: Stocks slide as concern about Ukraine trumps the strong jobs report.
description: Stocks have been zigzagging for the last several weeks as tension in Ukraine escalated and as sanctions on Russia, imposed in the days since its invasion of Ukraine, have mounted.
content: Stocks tumbled on Friday, with European indexes reaching their lowest point in about a year, as fighting intensified in Ukraine and government officials accused Russia of shelling Europe’s largest nuclear power facility, starting a fire that was later extinguished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: ‘I Want Peace.’ Zelensky’s Heroic Resistance Is an Example for the World.
description: Which world leaders are rising to the challenge?
content: As Russia’s leader holds his ground in his invasion of Ukraine, increasingly isolated from the rest of the world, the leadership of the United States and its European allies becomes ever more essential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Who Doesn’t Need a Portable Fog Machine?
description: The hottest accessory in Paris, for fashion-forward magicians.
content: There’s a lot to see at fashion week. Blink (or scroll too fast) and you’ll miss the details: feathered bags, futuristic sunglasses, fork jewelry. All month long, we’ll spotlight the things we saw that surprised or delighted us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Miller
title: Becoming a Woman Without Her
description: In my mother’s absence, I’m learning how to construct a sense of self — and femininity — from fragments, friends, music and memories.
content: My mother told me not to start shaving my legs without telling her. I disobeyed. One late November evening when I was 11, I noticed a razor, rusty and purple, beckoning to me in the shower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: For a State Representative, the Ideal Candidate
description: Malcolm Kenyatta, a politician in Pennsylvania, worried Matthew Miller was too good to be true after they connected on social media. He proved even better than expected.
content: It wasn’t long after Malcolm Kenyatta began messaging Matthew Jordan Miller on Instagram in April 2016 that Mr. Kenyatta started to wonder if the man he had started talking to was bad news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Ken Duberstein, a Former Reagan Chief of Staff, Dies at 77
description: He helped revive the Reagan presidency in its last years and became a respected lobbyist in Washington.
content: WASHINGTON — Ken Duberstein, a former White House chief of staff who helped resuscitate Ronald Reagan’s presidency and went on to become a successful lobbyist whose counsel was sought by leaders of both parties, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Putin’s Other Big Miscalculation
description: What will isolation do to the Russian economy?
content: Despite the astonishingly effective fight Ukraine has put up against invading forces, most military experts seem to believe that Russia’s sheer advantage in firepower will eventually prevail. Having no relevant expertise, I see no reason to question their judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: This Time, Beeple Is Trying His Hand at Artwork for Walls
description: The digital artist known for NFTs is showing paintings and prints IRL at a Manhattan gallery. Will the art establishment finally take notice?
content: A cavalry of crypto enthusiasts funneled into Manhattan’s TriBeCa neighborhood on Thursday evening, waiting outside Jack Hanley Gallery for a chance to meet their online art messiah in the flesh. In the mix were celebrities like Jimmy Fallon. It was a rock-star welcome for Mike Winkelmann, the digital artist known as Beeple, who was putting the final touches on his images of decapitated tech executives and haywire science experiments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Fareed Zakaria
description: A discussion with columnist and foreign policy advisor Fareed Zakaria.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Fareed Zakaria. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Week That Awoke the World
description: What the Ukrainians have taught us.
content: Over the last several years, that famous poem has been quoted countless times: “The centre cannot hold,” William Butler Yeats wrote, before adding, “The best lack all conviction, while the worst / Are full of passionate intensity.” People cited it so often because it was true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Kellen Browning
title: Washington State Advances Landmark Deal on Gig Drivers’ Job Status
description: Lawmakers have passed legislation granting benefits and protections, but allowing Lyft and Uber to continue to treat drivers as contractors.
content: The Washington State Senate on Friday passed a bill granting gig drivers certain benefits and protections while preventing them from being classified as employees — a longstanding priority of ride-hailing companies like Uber and Lyft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Decades of Neglect Leave I.R.S. in Tax Season ‘Chaos’
description: A shortage of staff and equipment has stalled America’s fiscal machinery.
content: WASHINGTON — At the Internal Revenue Service’s sprawling Kansas City, Mo., processing center, teams of clerks earning $15 per hour work through the night, trying to help the agency clear a backlog of more than 20 million tax returns that are a year overdue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks feature a ruthless wendigo, a cloistered bloodsucker, a bayou demon, wily jungle spirits and a grinning fiend named Rotcreep.
content: Max (Booboo Stewart) and Avery (Scarlett Sperduto) spend their flirty date strolling the quiet streets of a small town. A bomb threat has shut down the movie theater where they were planning to catch “The Evil Dead,” so instead Avery takes Max to the middle of nowhere to explore an old house she says is haunted. There, the two wander upstairs into a furnished bedroom, where Avery surprises Max with a story about Rotcreep, a fiendish entity who she warns is hungry. Like, right now hungry. Talk about leading a guy on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘On Sugarland’ Review: A Nameless War, and Too Many Wounds to Count
description: Inspired by Sophocles’ “Philoctetes,” Aleshea Harris uses poetic language, songs and symbolism to explore the trauma of being alive, especially for Black people.
content: Let’s begin with the war. Not the war that’s in the headlines. Not Iraq or Vietnam. I’m talking about war as metaphor. And in the realm of metaphor, anything can happen: A veteran’s wound may incessantly — and inexplicably — bleed for years, and a slain soldier’s daughter may have the ability to raise the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Restores Death Sentence for Boston Marathon Bomber
description: The Biden administration, which announced a moratorium on federal executions, has pursued the case against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who helped carry out the 2013 bombings.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday reinstated the death sentence of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted of helping carry out the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings that killed three and injured hundreds more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Suspends Advertising in Russia
description: The move came after a Russian regulator demanded that the company stop showing ads with what the regulator claimed was false information about the invasion of Ukraine.
content: Google said on Thursday night that it had suspended all advertising in Russia after the country’s internet regulator demanded that the company stop showing what it considered ads displaying false information about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Conway
title: A Snake-Inspired Bracelet Watch Evolves Once More
description: Reminiscent of a style made famous by Elizabeth Taylor, the latest iteration of Bulgari’s Serpenti timepiece has turquoise scales and rubellite eyes.
content: Bulgari’s Serpenti totem has assumed many forms in the 74 years since its debut in postwar Italy. The jeweler’s earliest snake-inspired pieces tended toward abstraction, referencing ophidian sinuousness by way of a corrugated gold bracelet — based on the articulated flex of gas piping — that slithered up the wrist. More recent designs, such as gem-wreathed watch faces shaped like a venomous snake’s triangular head, have mimicked the creature’s slinky form more directly. But it is the Italian house’s bold creations from the 1950s and ’60s, those with the most recognizably reptilian features, that have influenced its newest collection of women’s timepieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Benjamin Weiser
title: Ex-Fox News Producer Broke Law With Work for Russian Oligarch, U.S. Says
description: John Hanick was on Konstantin Malofeev’s payroll after Mr. Malofeev’s backing of Crimean separatists led to sanctions, an indictment says.
content: A former Fox News producer was charged on Thursday with violating U.S. sanctions by working for a Russian oligarch who has been accused of being a leading financial supporter of separatists in Crimea and eastern Ukraine and has close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Roasts Ron DeSantis for Berating Teens
description: Meyers said Florida’s governor was like “an old man who sees a bunch of innocent teens walking by and screams, ‘Hey, you kids get on my lawn!’”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Gary North, Apostle of Bible-Based Economics, Dies at 80
description: A prolific economic historian, he sought to infiltrate the conservative Christian and libertarian mainstream but never got too far from the fringe.
content: Gary North, an economic historian who found a wide audience in America’s far right and libertarian movements with his call for a Bible-based economic agenda under a harsh Christian theocracy, died on Feb. 24 in Dallas, Ga. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: In These Women’s Hands, Dating Is Truly the Stuff of Horror
description: The filmmakers behind “Fresh” worked to avoid being exploitative as they injected comedy into their commentary on the exploitation of women.
content: When the comedy screenwriter Lauryn Kahn first tried her hand at horror, a friend told her to write about the thing that scared her the most. She chose dating. After all, what’s more terrifying than relying on blind faith and a few Google searches to determine whether a complete stranger is a dud, a narcissist or, worse, a charming sociopath?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Akaash Singh and His Case for Bringing Back Apu
description: The stand-up comic, whose special has gone viral, takes issue with how some South Asians like Hari Kondabolu portray their experience in the United States.
content: When “The Simpsons” stopped using the Indian convenience store owner Apu in new episodes, many saw it as a hard-won victory against cultural stereotypes. The Indian American comic Akaash Singh was not one of them. In fact, he was upset about it — and as stand-ups do, he brought that onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: The Fish That Makes Me Want to Cook
description: Zainab Shah’s tender, tomatoey kharra masala fish will get you excited to be in the kitchen.
content: At the end of another week in this world of ours, I saw an article appear with the headline “19 Extremely Easy Recipes for When You’re Burned Out,” written by my wonderful colleague Margaux Laskey. I felt so seen, to use the parlance of our times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and William J. Broad
title: Fire at a Ukrainian nuclear plant is out, but Russian troops take control of the site.
description: International observers and Ukrainian officials said that as of 6 a.m. the facility was still able to function safely.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian troops seized control of Europe’s largest nuclear power plant in southeastern Ukraine before dawn on Friday, according to Ukrainian officials, but a fire set off by a raging gun battle had been extinguished. The fighting and fire had raised worldwide alarm because of the potential that they could reach and damage the nuclear reactors and cause a radiation leak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: In Short Supply: Everything From Chocolate to Headstone Stencils
description: Supply chain issues have hurt old-fashioned businesses as well as high-tech ones, and monument makers are among those feeling the pain.
content: Good morning. How far do supply chain issues reach? Today we’ll look at an unlikely niche of the New York economy that is coping with them. We’ll also hear from a big band that’s swinging again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: In Kyiv’s Railway Station, Rumors, Near-Stampedes and Frustration
description: As Russian forces begin to encircle the Ukrainian capital, tens of thousands are clambering for a way out that may soon be closed off.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The crowds of exhausted, frightened women and children at Kyiv’s central train station on Friday suddenly surged in a near-stampede to a station platform where a train heading to safety in western Ukraine was rumored to be arriving soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
title: With Sanctions, U.S. and Europe Aim to Punish Putin and Fuel Russian Unrest
description: The Biden administration and European officials are crushing the Russian economy and stirring mass anxiety to pressure President Vladimir V. Putin to end his war in Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — As they impose historic sanctions on Russia, the Biden administration and European governments have set new goals: devastate the Russian economy as punishment for the world to witness, and create domestic pressure on President Vladimir V. Putin to halt his war in Ukraine, current and former U.S. officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: The Buzzy Band Wet Leg Trips Out at a Party, and 13 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Bartees Strange, La Marimba, Sharon Van Etten and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Artist Who Painted a City
description: As Jesse Marsch takes over Leeds United, he faces the difficult task of replacing Marcelo Bielsa, who was equal parts coach and icon.
content: Out on the Burley Road, where the last vestiges of the city of Leeds slowly dissolve into the Yorkshire countryside, there is a barn in the middle of a field. It stands there, alone, the size of a garden shed, in a patch of land demarcating the boundary between a pet grooming salon and a dog park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Sahith Theegala Is a Rarity on the PGA Tour in More Ways Than One
description: The Indian American golfer is consistently finding his game as a rookie on tour, but he still lives with his parents and drives a regular old car.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Sahith Theegala, whose humble public golf course roots, unpretentious mien and near victory at last month’s Waste Management Phoenix Open have made him a rising young star on the PGA Tour, ended his round on Thursday with a dispiriting three-putt bogey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Raphael Xavier, Breaking Out of Boxes, Barely
description: “The Musician & the Mover,” a new work from the respected B-boy, had its New York premiere at New York Live Arts on Thursday.
content: As the choreographer Rennie Harris established decades ago, the dance language of hip-hop — developed on the streets and in battles — can be as broadly and deeply expressive as any other dance form. He showed that it can be transferred to the stage, and also transformed into metaphor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Lindsey Graham says of Putin: Someone in Russia should ‘take this guy out.’
description: The comments drew sharp rebukes from other Republicans.
content: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, called on Thursday night for the assassination of President Vladimir V. Putin, saying in a television interview as Russian forces shelled a nuclear power plant in Ukraine that somebody in Russia should “step up to the plate” and “take this guy out.”

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: What to Read About the Russia-Ukraine War

content: A week after Vladimir Putin ordered Russian forces to invade Ukraine, triggering the biggest military mobilization in Europe since World War II, cities are lying in ruin and a million people have fled the country.

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can I Still Wear Army Green?
description: A reader wonders if it’s time to retire a beloved pair of cargo pants.
content: Fashion has been enamored of military style for almost its entire existence, with designers regularly taking inspiration from all branches of the armed forces, be it color, shape, print, decoration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and William J. Broad
title: Combat at Ukraine Nuclear Plant Adds Radioactive Dangers to Russian Invasion
description: While Zaporizhzhia appeared secure on Friday, Russia’s seizure of the vast energy production site and potential targeting of another nuclear plant created risks of an accident.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — In darkness, Russia captured Europe’s largest nuclear power plant on Friday in Ukraine, prompting questions about the reasons it invaded the sprawling reactor site as well as the health risks to Ukrainians fighting desperately for their lives and freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: A Manhattan Chef Heads Upstate. A Country Tavern Follows.
description: Clare de Boer, who won accolades at King, is branching out with Stissing House, in a former Hudson Valley inn.
content: PINE PLAINS, N.Y. — It’s a fantasy many New Yorkers share: Move upstate, restore an old house, escape the noise of the city. But Clare de Boer, who will open her first solo restaurant, Stissing House, on Thursday, knows this isn’t some romantic endeavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Sides With F.B.I. in Case on Spying on Muslims
description: In a narrow and unanimous decision, the justices ruled that a 1978 law governing national security surveillance did not displace the state secrets doctrine.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday unanimously rejected an argument that could have limited the sweep of the state secrets doctrine in a case arising from the surveillance of Muslims in Southern California in 2006.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: ‘Traitors Get Shot’: Son Testifies Against Father in Jan. 6 Trial
description: Guy Reffitt’s 19-year-old son took the stand against him in federal court in a remarkable tableau that captured how one family was split by the attack on the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — When an oil-field worker named Guy Wesley Reffitt returned to Texas after taking part in the attack on the Capitol last year, his welcome home was not entirely warm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Adam Satariano
title: Russia blocks Facebook inside the country, as the Kremlin moves to stifle dissent.
description: Facebook on Friday became the first American tech giant to be blocked by the Russian government, as part of the Kremlin’s broadening campaign to tighten control of the internet and limit spaces for dissent about the war in Ukraine.
content: Facebook on Friday became the first American tech giant to be blocked by the Russian government, as part of the Kremlin’s broadening campaign to tighten control of the internet and limit spaces for dissent about the war in Ukraine.

author: By Candace Jackson
title: Why So Many People Became Real Estate Agents in the Pandemic
description: The industry is drawing workers while nearly every other job sector has struggled with hiring. As few as 10 percent of them will last long enough to make a full-time living selling homes.
content: In March 2020 when the pandemic hit, the restaurant where Amy Bieganek was working as a waitress announced a temporary closure. By August, it turned into a permanent one.

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: Washington’s Newest Worry: The Dangers of Cornering Putin
description: Surprised by the speed at which sanctions have been poured on Russia, Biden’s top aides suspect that Putin’s reaction will be to double down and lash out — and perhaps expand the war.
content: WASHINGTON — Senior White House officials designing the strategy to confront Russia have begun quietly debating a new concern: that the avalanche of sanctions directed at Moscow, which have gained speed faster than they imagined, is cornering President Vladimir V. author: By Patricia Mazzei and Alexandra Glorioso
title: Florida Lawmakers Vote to Ban Abortions After 15 Weeks
description: The legislation is modeled after an abortion law in Mississippi that the Supreme Court appears poised to uphold in a ruling expected this summer.
content: MIAMI — Florida legislators voted to ban most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy on Thursday, a move that would severely restrict access to the procedure in a state that for decades has been a refuge for women from across the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: The Battle for a Nuclear Plant
description: The fighting in Ukraine came as the Kremlin stepped up moves to stifle dissent in Russia.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauntel Lowe
title: The W.N.B.A.’s $20 Million Debate Over Leg Room, Luxury and Health
description: Secret charter flights cost the Liberty a big fine, but players say they deserve them — and need them to be healthy. The league says they’re too expensive for now.
content: The W.N.B.A. said charter flights were too expensive. The players said they did not have to be. The W.N.B.A. commissioner said she wanted them more than anyone. The players said that when they asked for them just two years ago, it felt like the answer was “a hard no.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Russia gains ground in southern Ukraine.
content: Russia and Ukraine concluded a second of round of talks in Belarus. They emerged with little progress toward a resolution of the conflict but agreed on establishing “humanitarian corridors” leading out of areas of intense fighting. Here are the latest updates.

author: By Alex Marshall
title: To Boycott Russians, or Not? In Film and Beyond, That’s the Question.
description: A Russian moviemaker with Ukrainian roots and relatives in Kyiv denounced the war. The Glasgow Film Festival dropped his film anyway.
content: The Russian filmmaker Kirill Sokolov has spent the past week distraught at the horror unfolding in Ukraine. Half his family is Ukrainian, he said in a telephone interview, and as a child he spent summers there, staying with his grandparents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Get Out of Your Pajamas, the Pandemic Is Over*
description: (*Or at least that’s the hope.) After several false starts, New York’s latest comeback finally feels like the real thing.
content: For the past several weeks, mayor Eric Adams has been exhorting businesses to get their employees back in the office, first making an appeal to conscience and then to cultural personality. Without a steady flow of commercial traffic, delis, restaurants, dry cleaners and all the remaining places that mix poke bowls while you wait on line will disappear, he has argued, endangering the livelihoods of hourly wage workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: U.S. Can’t Use Health Rule to Expel Migrant Families Facing Persecution, Court Says
description: An appeals court said the Biden administration could continue expelling migrant families under the pandemic-era rule, but not to countries where they would be persecuted.

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Dancer and a Scientist Walk Into a Bar

title: Tech Offers a Silver Lining in Ukraine

It is a gripping and tragic narrative being broadcast in real time, which led me to spend much of the past week talking to a range of cybersecurity and disinformation experts about the implications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: ‘I Don’t Want to Be Called Russian Anymore’: Anxious Soviet Diaspora Rethinks Identity
description: Immigrants from the former Soviet bloc were never a monolith, but they bonded over shared language and history. Now, they are shifting away from being seen as one group.
content: LOS ANGELES — Outside Babushka Grandma’s deli in the heart of Hollywood, immigrants from Russia, Ukraine and other countries that were part of the former Soviet Union sipped coffee and nibbled on piroshkis during a recent warm, sun-drenched afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dickson
title: He Break Dances. He Pole Dances. He Sings Like an Angel.

description: Over the span of two decades, the designer has transformed the traditional men’s wear staple into a radical and deeply contemporary look for all.
content: NEW YORK IS a city lived out in the open, a place where, pandemic or not, you see people in captivating outfits every day. But two decades after the 56-year-old American fashion designer Thom Browne established his line, it’s still startling to see someone wearing one of his suits out in the wild. These devotees typically adhere to Browne’s proportional dictates for his signature shrunken 1950s-inspired tailoring: The trousers should be hemmed short, rising two or three inches above sockless black leather brogues; their cuffs should likewise approach three inches. The matching three-button jacket, cut high in the armholes — both broadening the shoulders and discouraging bad posture — should be fastened only once, snugly around the rib cage, from which the blazer should skim six inches over the pants’ waist. Its truncated sleeves should reveal an inch of white shirt cuffs underneath, and don’t forget the white pocket square, which “should be ironed, and stick out only one-third inch,” as one guide published by the brand explains.
